P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will NATO conduct joint military exercises with Ukraine before 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if NATO conducts joint military exercises with Ukraine before January 1, 2028. The exercises must be officially announced and involve active participation of NATO member states alongside Ukrainian armed forces, with a minimum duration of 3 days. The exercises must be reported by at least two reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) to ensure credibility. Any informal or unofficial training sessions do not count towards this resolution.

Q.title: Will Ukraine resolve its territorial disputes with Russia before being accepted into NATO?

Q.title: Will Ukraine receive a Membership Action Plan from NATO by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, NATO officially provides Ukraine with a Membership Action Plan (MAP). The MAP must be formally announced in a NATO communiqué or through an official statement from NATO's leadership. The criteria for the MAP includes a clear outline of the steps Ukraine must take to advance towards NATO membership, and it must be recognized as such by NATO member states. In case of ambiguity, a MAP is defined as a program of advice, assistance, and support tailored to the specific needs of the aspirant country, aimed at helping it achieve its membership goals. If the MAP is offered but later rescinded, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will Ukraine's membership in NATO lead to a significant increase in military aid from Western countries by 2026?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2026, Ukraine's membership in NATO is officially recognized and leads to a measurable increase in military aid from Western countries. The increase must be at least 25% compared to the military aid levels provided in 2022. This military aid must include lethal and non-lethal assistance, and be confirmed by official statements from NATO member countries or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). In the absence of an official announcement, credible reports from reputable sources will suffice. Any aid provided under prior agreements or as part of ongoing support without the context of NATO membership will not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new infectious disease prompt the development of nuclear biocontainment technologies before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a new infectious disease emerges that leads to the development and deployment of nuclear biocontainment technologies. A 'new infectious disease' is defined as a pathogen that has not previously been identified in humans and is capable of human-to-human transmission, leading to an outbreak. The development of nuclear biocontainment technologies must be officially recognized and reported by a reputable source such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The technologies must be operational and intended for use against the new infectious disease, and not merely proposed or in the planning stages. If the technologies are developed for multiple diseases, the question will still resolve as Yes if the new infectious disease is included in the scope of the technologies.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease outbreak prompt the establishment of a dedicated international agency for infectious disease response by 2032?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2032, a new infectious disease outbreak occurs that leads to the establishment of a dedicated international agency specifically focused on infectious disease response. The outbreak must be recognized by the World Health Organization (WHO) and result in a formal announcement by at least two major countries or international bodies regarding the need for such an agency. The agency must be operational and have a defined mandate that includes coordination of international responses to infectious disease threats. The resolution will not count temporary task forces or committees but must involve a permanent agency with sustained funding and authority.

Q.title: Will significant advancements in vaccine technology occur as a result of a new infectious disease outbreak by 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, any of the following significant advancements in vaccine technology are recognized and documented as a direct result of a new infectious disease outbreak:

1. Development of a new vaccine platform that demonstrates efficacy in clinical trials against the outbreak disease.
2. Significant improvements in vaccine production methods that reduce time to market for a vaccine in response to the outbreak, as recognized by regulatory agencies such as the FDA or EMA.
3. Successful implementation of a novel delivery method for vaccines that is adopted in response to the outbreak and shows improved efficacy or accessibility.

Advancements must be reported by reputable sources, including peer-reviewed journals or major news outlets (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), and must be acknowledged by public health organizations such as the WHO or CDC. The advancements must not be incremental improvements but rather substantial innovations directly linked to the outbreak.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease result in the creation of a global health surveillance system by 2035?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, a global health surveillance system is officially established in response to a new infectious disease that meets the following criteria: 
- The system must be designed to monitor, report, and respond to infectious disease outbreaks on a global scale, with participation from multiple countries and international health organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO).
- The surveillance system must include real-time data collection, analysis, and sharing mechanisms that allow for rapid identification and response to infectious disease threats.
- The creation of this system must be documented by official reports, declarations, or agreements from recognized global health authorities, such as the WHO, and must be operational, not merely proposed or in a planning stage.
- In the event of a partial implementation, the question will resolve as Yes if the system is intended for global application and not limited to specific regions or countries. Temporary or ad-hoc systems for specific outbreaks do not count towards this resolution.

Q.title: Will governments increase funding for pandemic preparedness measures due to a new infectious disease by 2027?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, any government (federal, state, or local) in a recognized country increases its budgetary allocation for pandemic preparedness measures in response to the emergence of a new infectious disease. The increase must be publicly documented and reported by reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post) or through official government announcements. The new infectious disease must be classified as a significant threat by the World Health Organization (WHO) or equivalent health authority, leading to a measurable increase in funding compared to the year prior. Temporary or one-time funding increases for specific events or emergencies that do not lead to sustained funding changes will not count towards this resolution.

Q.title: Will a new infectious disease lead to the establishment of international biocontainment protocols by 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, an infectious disease emerges that leads to the establishment of internationally recognized biocontainment protocols. The following conditions must be met for the protocols to be considered established: 1. The protocols must be formally adopted by at least three major international health organizations, such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), or the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC). 2. The protocols must be implemented in response to the disease, addressing containment measures, travel restrictions, and public health guidelines. 3. The disease must be classified as a significant threat to global health, as determined by the aforementioned organizations. 4. The establishment of protocols must be publicly announced and documented in reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). If multiple diseases emerge, the resolution will be based on the first disease that meets these criteria.

P.title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially granted membership in NATO, as confirmed by a formal announcement from NATO's Secretary General or the NATO Summit. The membership must be ratified by all current NATO member states, and Ukraine must fulfill all necessary criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's membership action plan. Any interim agreements or partnerships will not count as membership. In the event of a membership application being approved but not yet ratified by all member states, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will NATO expand its presence in Eastern Europe in response to Ukraine's potential membership by 2029?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2029, NATO has officially expanded its military presence in Eastern Europe as a direct response to Ukraine's potential membership in NATO. This includes any increase in troop deployments, establishment of new bases, or significant military exercises conducted in Eastern European NATO member countries specifically citing Ukraine's membership as a reason for the expansion. The decision must be confirmed through official NATO communications or credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post). Any temporary deployments or exercises not explicitly linked to Ukraine's membership will not count towards this resolution.
